docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today rejected a proposal to eliminate a finding that Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria, in violation of the Charter, had "given assistance and...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today rejected a proposal to eliminate a finding that Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria, in violation of the Charter, had "given assistance and support to the guerrillas fighting against the Greek Government."
docs.abstract: Assembly com rejects proposal to drop guilt charges; Assembly passage of guilt finding seen impossible; US agrees to accept Brit proposal noting evidence of guilt and urging countries to stop aid to guerrillas; Assembly com votes on border com membership; leaves seats open for USSR and Poland

headline.main: U.N. Unit Bars Move to Drop Finding of Guilt in Balkans; But Vote of 29 to 6, With 16 Abstentions and 6 Absent, May Mean United States Resolution Will Fail Later U.N. UNIT REJECTS BALKAN PROPOSAL

docs.snippet: LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton's speech to bankers here last night had a two-way effect on the stock markets today.

headline.main: BONDS AND SHARES ON LONDON MARKET; Dalton's Speech to Bankers Sends Some Securities Up and Depresses Others

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 -- President Juan Peron yesterday devoted a full-length radio speech to the menace of locusts to Argentina's agricultural economy. This unusual step reflected not only the pests' serious depredations, which may eventually be...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 -- President Juan Peron yesterday devoted a full-length radio speech to the menace of locusts to Argentina's agricultural economy. This unusual step reflected not only the pests' serious depredations, which may eventually be reflected in the world food shortage, but it also made clear that the foes of the regime have been using the plague as an argument in rural communities that the Government was ignoring them.
docs.abstract: Pres Peron warns of crops peril; asks pub aid; denies Govt lag; plague described; Argentine press reaction

headline.main: PERON ISSUES CALL TO WAR ON LOCUSTS; Argentine Asserts 2,470,000 Acres Are Menaced -- Throws Planes Into Fight on Pests

byline.original: By VIRGINIA LEE WARRENSpecial to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: LONDON, Oct. 13 -- A fresh advance by Government securities and the continued weakness of industrial shares marked the trading in the stock markets here today.

headline.main: GILT-EDGE ISSUES STRONG IN LONDON; Speculative Demand Persists, Rise Since Dalton's Speech Averaging 2 1/2 Points INDUSTRIALS UNCERTAIN Losses Range to 3s. as Sequel to Morrison's Statement on Prospective Changes

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- The Yugoslav delegation proposed today in the United Nations General Assembly's Special Committee on Palestine that all Jewish, refugees now interned in the stockades of Cyprus be admitted to Palestine immediately...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- The Yugoslav delegation proposed today in the United Nations General Assembly's Special Committee on Palestine that all Jewish, refugees now interned in the stockades of Cyprus be admitted to Palestine immediately without regard to "present immigration quotas or future provisions."
docs.abstract: Announces filing memo with UN calling for Security Council action to prevent Arab breach of peace

headline.main: YUGOSLAV BIDS U.N. FREE CYPRUS JEWS; Seeks Palestine Entry Now Regardless of Quota Law or Future Provisions

docs.snippet: LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Five more nations lined up today behind the United States plan for a "Little Assembly" but the Slav group continued to hammer away at the proposal as a scheme that would wreck the chance for any Anglo-American-Soviet...
docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Five more nations lined up today behind the United States plan for a "Little Assembly" but the Slav group continued to hammer away at the proposal as a scheme that would wreck the chance for any Anglo-American-Soviet cooperation.

headline.main: FIVE NATIONS BACK 'LITTLE ASSEMBLY'; Yugoslav, Czech Score U.S. Proposal--Dulles and Evatt Bear Brunt of Charges

docs.snippet: Thursday, Oct. 16, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Continued discussion of United States proposal for yearround "Little Assembly" and received Australian proposal to refer it to subcommittee for study;...
docs.lead_paragraph: Thursday, Oct. 16, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Continued discussion of United States proposal for yearround "Little Assembly" and received Australian proposal to refer it to subcommittee for study; also heard representatives of Uruguay, China, Yugoslavia, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Turkey and El Salvador.
